matter_wave_hypothesis.title: Matter Wave Hypothesis
matter_wave_hypothesis.content: De Broglie proposed that all matter exhibits wave-like properties, extending wave-particle duality from light to all particles with mass. This revolutionary idea earned him the Nobel Prize when electron diffraction was experimentally confirmed.

debroglie_formula.title: The de Broglie Formula
debroglie_formula.content: The de Broglie wavelength λ = h/p shows that wavelength is inversely proportional to momentum. This means faster or heavier particles have shorter wavelengths.
keyPoints: Smaller mass → larger wavelength at same velocity
Higher velocity → smaller wavelength for same mass

photon_momentum.title: Photon Momentum
photon_momentum.content: Despite having no mass, photons carry momentum p = E/c = h/λ. This momentum can transfer to matter, enabling technologies like solar sails and optical tweezers.

diffraction_imaging.title: Diffraction and Imaging Limits
diffraction_imaging.content: The resolution of any imaging system is fundamentally limited by diffraction. When the wavelength approaches the size of features being imaged (λ/w ≥ 1), significant diffraction occurs, blurring the image.

wave_particle_duality.title: Wave-Particle Duality
wave_particle_duality.content: The double slit experiment with single particles demonstrates that light and matter exhibit both wave and particle properties simultaneously. Each particle creates a discrete impact (particle nature) but collectively forms an interference pattern (wave nature).
philosophicalImplications: Particles exist in superposition until measured
Wave and particle are complementary descriptions
